From: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
>
> I think, if I understand this discussion, what's wanted is a protocol
> between user and UA, in which login session does exist, such that
> the UA knows when to stop sending the credentials to the server.
> That would constitute a logout.  There's certainly nothing wrong with
> maintaining a session between user and UI, is there?  Otherwise,
> the user has to type credentials over and over, which is no good.

But the user *does* have to type credentials over and over.  Fortunately,
the browser is doing the work for him.  Why would a RESTful application care
whether the user was "logged in" or "logged out"?  All the server should
care about is that the user is authorized.

Now, I do understand the security risk(s) here.  Until the browser is closed
or the server sends another 401 for the same realm, that browser (or
whatever agent) basically has the security clearance of the user.  Since
there is no guarantee that the same user will be using that instance of the
browser, there is the possibility for someone else to get into the system
with the wrong credentials.  However, I do not believe this is a problem for
the server to solve.  Instead, I think it's important to improve the client.

Here are some suggestions:

1) When a browser is sending authentication with each request, prominantly
provide a button on the screen labeled "clear authentication" (or some
such).  A user can click on this at any time to force the browser to dump
the authentication.

2) When the user leaves the authenticated page/realm, have the browser
prompt the user as to whether the authentication information should be
cleared or not.  This way, a user does not have to depend on #1 above or on
closing the browser in order to go to another website.

3) Just as you would expect for gaining access to other everyday items,
require the user to authenticate himself to the browser via biometrics, an
access card, etc.  In other words, the user-to-browser credentials should
leave with the user and cause the browser-to-server credentials to be
cleared immediately.

Again, I think the "logout"/security problem is not with the server.  We
should not be solving it at the server.  The weakness is with the
browser/user-agent and that's where it should be fixed. imho, of course.
